#.title: 51% Attack
#.excerpt: Also known as a Majority Attack. When one or a group of miners control greater than 50% of the network's mining hashrate or computational power.

a.title: Absolute Advantage
a.excerpt: An economics concept in which one party has a direct advantage in efficiency in producing/providing a specific good or service over another party.

a.title: Active Management
a.excerpt: An investing strategy employed by fund managers aiming to outperform an index or market in order to generate profits.

a.title: Ad Hoc
a.excerpt: A phrase of Latin origin that is used in modern English to mean 'for this purpose' or 'specifically for this.'

a.title: Address
a.excerpt: String of text that designates the location of a particular wallet on the blockchain. Often a hashed version of a public key.

a.title: Airdrop
a.excerpt: The distribution of digital assets to the public, either by virtue of holding a certain other token or simply by virtue of being an active wallet address on a particular blockchain

a.title: Algorithm
a.excerpt: A sequence of unambiguous instructions used for the purpose of solving a problem.

a.title: All or None Order AON
a.excerpt: An order which once placed, must either be filled in its entirety or not at all. This prevents any partial filling of orders.

a.title: All-Time High ATH
a.excerpt: The highest price of a cryptocurrency in a quote​ currency, such as a dollar, BTC, ETH, or BNB

a.title: Allocation
a.excerpt: An allotment of tokens or equity, that may be earned, purchased, or set aside for a certain investor, team, group, organization, or other related entity.

a.title: Alpha
a.excerpt: The first look at a product released by a team, consisting of the very first version of a primitive, basic software or product.

a.title: Altcoin
a.excerpt: A cryptocurrency that is alternative to Bitcoin. Used to describe cryptocurrencies that are not Bitcoin.

a.title: Angel Investor
a.excerpt: Wealthy investors that seek out opportunities to provide funding for entrepreneurs or start-up companies.

a.title: Anti Money Laundering AML
a.excerpt: A framework consisting of legal and regulatory procedures to minimize and curb the flow of funds that are generated from illegal or dubious activities.

a.title: Application Programming Interface API
a.excerpt: A collection of functions and procedures that allow users to interact/communicate with the data of an application or service, such as an exchange, to execute the features of the service programmatically.

a.title: Application-Specific Integrated Circuit ASIC
a.excerpt: An Integrated Circuit customized for maximum performance in a particular use, rather than general-purpose use.

a.title: Arbitrage
a.excerpt: Buying and selling of assets over different markets in order to take advantage of differing prices on the same asset.

a.title: ASIC-resistant
a.excerpt: An ASIC-resistant cryptocurrency has its protocol and mining algorithm configured in such a way that using ASIC machines to mine the coin is either impossible or brings no significant benefit when compared to traditional GPU mining.

a.title: Ask Price
a.excerpt: The lowest price a seller is willing to accept on their sell order when trading an asset on an exchange.

a.title: Asset Management
a.excerpt: A system or method that helps individuals or companies manage assets. Either on behalf of their clients or their own.

a.title: Asynchronous
a.excerpt: Events in electronic systems that do not happen at the same time or speed, or happen independent of the main program flow.

a.title: Atomic Swap
a.excerpt: Smart contract technology that enables the exchange of one cryptocurrency for another without using centralized intermediaries, such as exchanges.

a.title: Attack surface
a.excerpt: Points in a software environment where an attacker can attempt to enter or extract data from the system.

a.title: Auction
a.excerpt: A live event where assets or services are negotiated through a bidding process, which is often led by an auctioneer.

b.title: Bags
b.excerpt: The portfolio of coins and tokens one is holding. Often related to a poorly performing bag of assets that investors insist to hold.

b.title: Bear Market
b.excerpt: A negative trend in prices of a market. It is widely used not only in the cryptocurrency space but also in the traditional markets.

b.title: Benchmark
b.excerpt: A measurement standard which can be used to gauge the performance of a particular asset or investment portfolio.

b.title: BEP-2
b.excerpt: A technical standard that defines a set of rules for the issuance and management of tokens in the Binance Chain ecosystem.

b.title: BEP-20
b.excerpt: BEP-20 is a token standard on Binance Smart Chain that extends ERC-20, the most common Ethereum token standard. You can think of it as a blueprint for tokens that defines how they can be spent, who can spend them, and other rules for their usage. Due to its similarity to Binance Chain’s BEP-2 and Ethereum’s ERC-20, it’s compatible with both.

b.title: BEP-721
b.excerpt: A technical standard that defines a set of rules for the issuance of NFTs in the Binance Smart Chain ecosystem.

b.title: BEP-95
b.excerpt: BEP-95 is a Binance Evolution Proposal that introduces a real-time burning mechanism to Binance Smart Chain.

b.title: Beta Coefficient
b.excerpt: A tool used to measure the volatility of an asset in comparison to the volatility of a specific portfolio or market index.

b.title: Beta Release
b.excerpt: An early version of a program for users to test and for a team to get feedback. Beta stage comes after the Alpha stage.

b.title: Bid Price
b.excerpt: In the context of financial markets, it is the value buyers offer for an asset, such as a commodity, security, or cryptocurrency.

b.title: Bid-Ask Spread
b.excerpt: The difference in price between the lowest asking price and highest bid price on the order book for an asset

b.title: Binance Blockchain Charity Foundation BCF
b.excerpt: The world's first decentralized charity platform to advocate the concept of 'blockchain for social good'.

b.title: Binance Community Vote
b.excerpt: When the community has the opportunity to vote for their favorite project to win a free listing on Binance.

b.title: Binance Ecosystem Fund BEF
b.excerpt: An initiative by Binance to collaborate with partners who care about the blockchain/cryptocurrency ecosystem.

b.title: Binance Labs
b.excerpt: A social impact fund and an initiative to incubate, invest, and empower blockchain and cryptocurrency entrepreneurs, projects, and communities.

b.title: Bitcoin
b.excerpt: A cryptocurrency created by the pseudonymous developers Satoshi Nakamoto. The first cryptocurrency, initially described as a 'Peer-to-Peer e-cash'.

b.title: Bitcoin Core
b.excerpt: Leading implementation of the software that enables users to interact with the Bitcoin network. Initially released by Satoshi.

b.title: Bitcoin Dominance
b.excerpt: The ratio of Bitcoin's market capitalization versus the sum of the market capitalizations of all cryptocurrencies.

b.title: Bitcoin Pizza
b.excerpt: The first known transaction where Bitcoin was exchanged for a physical good. Laszlo Hanyecz paid 10,000 BTC for two pizzas.

b.title: Black Swan Event
b.excerpt: An event that is often entirely unexpected and deviates from the expected result causing widespread ramifications.

b.title: Block
b.excerpt: A computer file that stores transaction data. These can then be arranged in a linear sequence, which will form a blockchain.

b.title: Block Explorer
b.excerpt: An online Blockchain webpage which allows users to browse information about blocks, transactions, balances, and transaction histories.

b.title: Block header
b.excerpt: A section in a block containing metadata and a summary of the block's transactions. This is the information hashed when mining.

b.title: Block Height
b.excerpt: The number of blocks in the chain between itself and the first block on that blockchain genesis block or block 0.

b.title: Block Reward
b.excerpt: The sum of coins awarded by the blockchain protocol to cryptocurrency miners for each successfully mined and validated block.

b.title: Blockchain
b.excerpt: A decentralized, digitized ledger that records transaction information about a cryptocurrency in a chronological order.

b.title: Bloom Filter
b.excerpt: A data structure that can be used to inform the user whether a particular item is part of a set

b.title: BNB
b.excerpt: Launched by Binance after an initial coin offering that ended on July 3rd, 2017. Used for receiving exchange trading fee discounts among other utilities.

b.title: Bollinger Bands
b.excerpt: A technical analysis indicator that measures market volatility. It's made of two sidelong bands and a simple moving average.

b.title: Bounty
b.excerpt: A reward posted by a group or individual to incentivize certain work, behavior such as referrals, or development.

b.title: Break-Even Point BEP
b.excerpt: The point where the total costs of an operation is equivalent to its current value or revenue.

b.title: Breakeven Multiple
b.excerpt: The multiple of the current price by which an asset needs to appreciate in order to reach its previous all-time high.

b.title: Breakout
b.excerpt: When the price of an asset moves outside of a defined range or pattern, typically by breaking out of a support or resistance area.

b.title: BUIDL
b.excerpt: Originally derived from HODL, a term referring to keeping your heads down and focusing on building your product.

b.title: Bull Market
b.excerpt: A positive trend in prices of a market. It is widely used not only in the cryptocurrency space but also in the traditional markets.

b.title: Buy Wall
b.excerpt: A single huge buy order or the composition of multiple large buy orders at the same price in the order book of a particular market.

c.title: Candidate Block
c.excerpt: A temporary block created by a mining node miner to add to the blockchain to receive the block rewards.

c.title: Candlestick
c.excerpt: A graph representation of price action that displays the open, close, high, and low points within a certain period.

c.title: Capitulation
c.excerpt: A period of strong selling activity, where investors give up their positions and sell their holdings as quickly as possible.

c.title: Censorship-resistance
c.excerpt: The property of a cryptocurrency network that prevents any entity from altering transactions on it.

c.title: Central Bank
c.excerpt: A financial institution that acts as a monetary authority and manages a states currency, interest rates, and money supply.

c.title: Central Processing Unit CPU
c.excerpt: The part of a computer responsible for interpreting instructions of computer programs and executing operations.

c.title: Centralized
c.excerpt: When the planning and decision-making mechanisms are concentrated in a particular point within a system.

c.title: Cipher
c.excerpt: A method for encrypting and decrypting messages. These can be divided into symmetric or asymmetric, according to their key model.

c.title: Circulating Supply
c.excerpt: The best approximate number of cryptocurrency coins or tokens that are publicly available and circulating in the market.

c.title: Cloud
c.excerpt: In computer science, a shared pool of resources, which are made available to multiple users through the Internet.

c.title: Coin
c.excerpt: A cryptocurrency or digital cash that is independent of any other platform, which is used as an exchange of value.

c.title: Collateral
c.excerpt: Pledging something of value against a loan to guarantee that the person taking the loan will complete repayment.

c.title: Colocation
c.excerpt: A dedicated space in a data center belonging to stock exchanges which is shared with other entities such as high-frequency traders.

c.title: Commodity Futures Trading Commission CFTC
c.excerpt: US-based agency responsible for regulating the derivatives markets, which includes options, swaps, and futures contracts.

c.title: Confirmation Time
c.excerpt: The time elapsed when a transaction is submitted to the network and the time it is recorded into a confirmed block.

c.title: Confluence
c.excerpt: When multiple investment methods, technical indicators, or trading signals are combined to form a more reliable strategy.

c.title: Consumer Price Index CPI
c.excerpt: A Consumer Price Index CPI is a measure used to track the effects of inflation over a period of time.

c.title: Credentials
c.excerpt: Personal information. Examples include username, password, email address, qualifications and many more.

c.title: Cryptocurrency
c.excerpt: A digital currency that is secured by cryptography to work as a medium of exchange within a peer-to-peer P2P economic system.

c.title: Cryptography
c.excerpt: The science of using mathematical theories and computation in order to encrypt and decrypt information.

c.title: Custody
c.excerpt: Refers to the holding of assets on behalf of a client. Can also refer to the ownership of one's funds or assets.

d.title: Daemon
d.excerpt: A process operating in the background waiting for a specific event or condition in order to be activated.

d.title: Dead Cat Bounce
d.excerpt: A brief recovery in the price of a declining asset that is shortly followed by a continuation of the downtrend.

d.title: Decentralized Application DApp
d.excerpt: Applications that run on a P2P network of computers rather than one central computer. This allows the software to run on the internet without being controlled by a single entity.

d.title: Decentralized Autonomous Cooperative DAC
d.excerpt: An organization that is controlled by shareholders rather than a central authority.

d.title: Decentralized Autonomous Organization DAO
d.excerpt: A system of hard-coded rules that define which actions a decentralized organization will take.

d.title: Decentralized Exchange DEX
d.excerpt: An exchange which does not require users to deposit funds to start trading and does not hold the funds for the user. Instead, users trade directly from their own wallets.

d.title: Decentralized Finance DeFi
d.excerpt: The ecosystem comprised of decentralized financial applications developed on top of blockchain networks.

d.title: Decryption
d.excerpt: The act of reverting an encryption process so that unreadable data ciphertext can be converted into readable data plaintext.

d.title: Deep Web
d.excerpt: The part of the web that is somehow hidden, i.e., not indexed by Google and other traditional web search engines.

d.title: Delisting
d.excerpt: The removal of an asset from an exchange either as a request from the project team or as a decision made by the exchange.

d.title: Design Flaw Attack
d.excerpt: An attack in which a malicious user purposely creates a smart-contract, decentralized market, or other software with knowledge of certain flaws in order to trick individuals interacting within the permissionless environment.

d.title: Diamond Hands
d.excerpt: Diamond hands refers to holding a financial asset and not selling it, regardless of its volatility.

d.title: Difficulty
d.excerpt: In cryptocurrency, difficulty indicates the difficulty required to mine a block. Learn more at Binance Academy.

d.title: Difficulty Bomb
d.excerpt: The term 'difficulty bomb' denotes the increase in mining difficulty in Ethereum, as part of its migration to Proof of Stake.

d.title: Divergence
d.excerpt: When the market price of an asset and a technical indicator e.g. RSI, Volume, MACD are heading in opposite directions.

d.title: Diversification
d.excerpt: The allocation of funds across different types of assets and jurisdictions in order to reduce the overall risks.

d.title: Do Your Own Research DYOR
d.excerpt: A valuable piece of advice. It's always wise to research a coin or token yourself instead of following what others say.

d.title: Dollar Cost Averaging DCA
d.excerpt: Investing fixed dollar amounts over regular periods of time regardless of the price of the asset.

d.title: Double Spending
d.excerpt: When a given amount of coins are spent more than once. Usually as a result of a race attack or a 51% attack.

e.title: Eclipse Attack
e.excerpt: When the majority of peers on the network are malicious and monopolize the network in order to prevent specific nodes from receiving information from honest nodes.

e.title: Efficient Market Hypothesis EMH
e.excerpt: An economic theory stating financial markets reflect all available information on the price of assets at any time.

e.title: Encryption
e.excerpt: Conversion of information or data into a secure code in order to prevent unauthorised access to the information or data.

e.title: Enterprise Ethereum Alliance EEA
e.excerpt: The industry’s first global standards organization to deliver an open, standards-based architecture and specification to accelerate the adoption of Enterprise Ethereum.

e.title: ERC-20
e.excerpt: A technical standard used to issue and implement tokens on the Ethereum blockchain proposed in November 2015 by Fabian Vogelsteller.

e.title: ERC-721
e.excerpt: An Ethereum based non-fungible token. This means that each token is unique and as a result, not interchangeable.

e.title: Exchange
e.excerpt: A marketplace for cryptocurrencies where users can buy and sell coins.

f.title: Fakeout
f.excerpt: A situation where a trader enters a position betting on a price movement that quickly reverses or ultimately doesn’t happen.

f.title: Falling Knife
f.excerpt: Refers to the action of purchasing an asset while it is rapidly declining in price under the expectation that it will bounce.

f.title: Fear Of Missing Out FOMO
f.excerpt: The feeling of fear and anxiety that you might be missing out on a potentially profitable opportunity.

f.title: Fear, Uncertainty and Doubt FUD
f.excerpt: A marketing strategy used to spread fear and insecurity among customers, traders, or investors.

f.title: Fiat
f.excerpt: Money that a government has declared to be legal tender.

f.title: Fill Or Kill Order FOK
f.excerpt: A buy or sell order which must be executed immediately in its entirety or else it will be cancelled.

f.title: Finality
f.excerpt: The assurance or guarantee that completed cryptocurrency transactions cannot be altered, reversed or canceled.

f.title: First-Mover Advantage FMA
f.excerpt: The competitive advantage of the first project to bring a service or product into a new and unexplored market or industry.

f.title: Fiscal Policy
f.excerpt: Describes how authorities adjusts the tax rates of a country, influencing how public funds should be collected and used.

f.title: Flappening
f.excerpt: The name to describe the moment when Litecoin LTC surpassed Bitcoin Cash BCH in terms of market capitalization

f.title: Flippening
f.excerpt: The name to describe the moment when/if Ethereum ETH surpasses Bitcoin BTC in terms of market capitalization

f.title: Forced Liquidation
f.excerpt: When a trader's leveraged position is forcibly closed as a result of it not fulfilling the necessary margin requirements.

f.title: Forex FX
f.excerpt: Forex stands for Foreign Exchange Markets. It's a global market for the trading of fiat currencies.

f.title: Formal Verification
f.excerpt: Using mathematically rigorous proofs to ensure certain properties of cryptographic algorithms and blockchain mechanisms

f.title: Full Node
f.excerpt: A computer that fully implements the entirety of rules of an underlying blockchain network and completely validates transactions and blocks on a blockchain.

f.title: Fundamental Analysis FA
f.excerpt: Evaluating an asset based on its underlying characteristics and traits as an effort towards arriving at an intrinsic value of the asset.

f.title: Fungibility
f.excerpt: The property of an asset whose individual units are indistinguishable from each other in terms of value and functionality.

f.title: Futures Contract
f.excerpt: A standardized version of forward contracts that are used as a legal agreement to buy or sell an asset in the future at an agreed upon price and date.

g.title: Gas
g.excerpt: The pricing mechanism employed  on the Ethereum blockchain to calculate the costs of smart contracts operations and transaction fees.

g.title: Gas Limit
g.excerpt: The maximum price a cryptocurrency user is willing to pay as a fee when sending a transaction, or performing a smart contract function.

g.title: General Public License
g.excerpt: License allowing users to copy and modify software, but requires the works to be distributed under the same license.

g.title: Genesis Block
g.excerpt: The first ever block recorded on its respective blockchain network, also referred to as Block 0 or Block 1.

g.title: GitHub
g.excerpt: A site/system/folder/repository where a team can share, collaborate, and save their open source or propietary code.

g.title: Golden Cross
g.excerpt: A bullish chart pattern where a shorter-term moving average crosses above a longer-term moving average.

g.title: Gossip Protocol
g.excerpt: A particular method of asynchronous peer-to-peer communication between computer nodes of a distributed system.

g.title: Gwei
g.excerpt: A small denomination of Ether. It is widely used as a measure of gas prices. 1,000,000,000 wei = 1 Giga wei Gwei

h.title: Hacker
h.excerpt: An individual that has an advanced understanding of computer systems and networks, including programmers and cybersecurity experts.

h.title: Haha Money Printer Go Brrrrr
h.excerpt: Haha Money Printer Go Brrrrr is meme created in response to the Federal Reserve's 2020 plan to print money.

h.title: Halving
h.excerpt: When the block reward of a crypto asset, such as bitcoin, drops to one-half of what it was before; this is used to create a decaying rate of issuance to arrive at an eventual finite supply of a crypto asset.

h.title: Hard Cap
h.excerpt: The maximum amount of funds a project intends to raise during their Initial Coin Offering ICO or alternative fundraising event.

h.title: Hash
h.excerpt: The output produced by a hash function after a piece of data is mapped. May also be referred to as hash value, hash code, or digest.

h.title: Hash Rate
h.excerpt: The speed at which a computer or mining hardware is able to calculate new hashes. Usually measured in hashes per second.

h.title: Hashed TimeLock Contract HTLC
h.excerpt: Refers to a special feature that is used to create smart contracts that are able to modify payment channels.

h.title: High-Frequency Trading HFT
h.excerpt: A type of algorithmic trading that involves the execution of a large number of orders in fractions of a second.

h.title: HODL
h.excerpt: A typo of 'Hold' originating from bitcointalk that has also been retrofitted to be an acronym for Hold on for Dear Life - to maintain ownership of coins and not sell.

h.title: Honeypot
h.excerpt: A mechanism used in computer security used to detect or counteract unauthorized access of information systems.

i.title: Iceberg Order
i.excerpt: A conditional order to buy or sell a large amount of assets in smaller predetermined quantities in order to conceal the total order quantity.

i.title: Immutability
i.excerpt: The inability to change or be changed. One of the core features behind Bitcoin and blockchain technology.

i.title: Index
i.excerpt: A financial instrument used to track the price value of a given asset or basket of assets

i.title: Initial Coin Offering ICO
i.excerpt: A fundraising method in which new projects will sell their cryptocurrency to investors.

i.title: Initial Exchange Offering IEO
i.excerpt: A fundraising method designed to reduce the risk for token purchasers by introducing a trusted intermediary between the project team and the user.

i.title: Initial Public Offering IPO
i.excerpt: Refers to the moment a private company starts offering its shares to the public for the first time.

i.title: Integrated Circuit IC
i.excerpt: A small chip, typically made of silicon, that holds a set of electronic parts such as transistors, resistors or capacitors.

i.title: Interoperability
i.excerpt: A concept of allowing blockchains to be compatible with each other and build upon each other's features and use-cases.

i.title: InterPlanetary File System IPFS
i.excerpt: An open-source project building a protocol for distributed content storage and access.

i.title: IOU
i.excerpt: An acronym which stands for “I owe you” and refers to an informal document that acknowledges a debt one party owes to another.

i.title: Isolated Margin
i.excerpt: The margin balance allocated to a position. Traders can manage risk by restricting the amount allocated to each position.

i.title: Issuance
i.excerpt: Generation of a new cryptocurrency which occurs in a variety of different ways, depending on parameters specified by the creators.

j.title: Jager
j.excerpt: The smallest denomination of BNB. Derived from the Telegram handle of the Binance Community Manager at the time.

k.title: Keccak
k.excerpt: A versatile cryptographic function designed by Guido Bertoni, Joan Daemen, Michaël Peeters, and Gilles Van Assche.

k.title: Know Your Customer KYC
k.excerpt: A standard procedure in the finance industry which allows companies to identify their customers and comply with KYC AML laws

l.title: Latency
l.excerpt: The time between submitting a transaction to a network and the first confirmation of acceptance by the network.

l.title: Law of Demand
l.excerpt: The law of demand relates to the willingness of consumers to buy a specific amount of goods or services for a particular price.

l.title: Layer 2
l.excerpt: A secondary framework or protocol that is built on top of an existing blockchain system to provide increased scalability.

l.title: Ledger
l.excerpt: A physical book or a digital computer file where monetary and financial transactions are tracked and recorded.

l.title: Library
l.excerpt: A collection of stable resources, which may include executable files, documentation, message templates, and written code.

l.title: Lightning Network
l.excerpt: A second layer operating on top of a blockchain, enabling increased transaction speed among participating nodes. This is one proposed scaling solution.

l.title: Linux
l.excerpt: A popular open-source operating system, created in 1991 by Linus Torvalds. It is used in a wide range of devices around the world.

l.title: Liquidity
l.excerpt: The ability to sell or buy any given asset without causing significant fluctuations in the market price for that asset.

l.title: Listing
l.excerpt: The addition of an asset to an exchange either as a request from the project team or as a decision made by the exchange.

m.title: Mainnet
m.excerpt: A blockchain protocol which is fully developed and deployed where transactions are being broadcasted, verified, and recorded.

m.title: Mainnet Swap
m.excerpt: When a coin migrates from a third party platform such as Ethereum or other token to a native on-chain token on their mainnet.

m.title: Maker
m.excerpt: You become a “maker” when you place an order and it does not trade immediately, so your order stays in the order book and waits for someone else to fill/match with it later.

m.title: Malware
m.excerpt: Any software program or code that is created to infiltrate and intentionally cause damage to computer systems and networks.

m.title: Margin Trading
m.excerpt: Trading using borrowed funds  - note: this is a high risk strategy and should only be done by experienced investors.

m.title: Market Capitalization
m.excerpt: The total trading value of a given coin - calculated by the product of the supply of the coin by the current price.

m.title: Market Momentum
m.excerpt: The ability of a certain market to maintain a continuous increase or decrease in price within a particular timeframe.

m.title: Market Order
m.excerpt: When a taker picks the best available bid or ask for a cryptocurrency, taking the price and quantity available on the order book.

m.title: Masternode
m.excerpt: Nodes on a network that often require a minimum amount of a given coin staked in order to access staking rewards.

m.title: Maximum Supply
m.excerpt: Refers to the maximum number of coins or tokens that will be ever created for a given cryptocurrency.

m.title: Mempool
m.excerpt: A node’s mechanism for keeping track of unconfirmed transactions that the node has seen but have not yet been added to a block.

m.title: Merged Mining
m.excerpt: The act of mining two or more cryptocurrencies at the same time, without sacrificing overall mining performance

m.title: Merkle Tree
m.excerpt: A way of organizing and structuring large amounts of data to make it more straightforward to process. A hash-based data structure.

m.title: Metadata
m.excerpt: Data that includes information about other data, such as information about features of a specific transaction.

m.title: Mining
m.excerpt: The verification of transactions on a blockchain network, in which transactions are added as entries into the blockchain ledger.

m.title: Mining Farm
m.excerpt: A collection of many miners, often in a warehouse or large data center devoted to mining cryptocurrencies

m.title: Monetary Policy
m.excerpt: Refers to the policies that authorities create and adopt to control the money supply and interest rates of a country.

m.title: Moon
m.excerpt: A colloquial expression used to describe a cryptocurrency or other asset that is experiencing a strong upward market trend.

m.title: Multisignature
m.excerpt: Wallet which requires another party to authorize a transaction before it is broadcasted to the network.

n.title: Node
n.excerpt: A participant on a blockchain network that communicates with other participants to ensure the security and integrity of the system.

n.title: Non-fungible Token NFT
n.excerpt: A type of cryptographic token that represents a unique digital or real-world asset and isn't interchangeable.

n.title: Nonce
n.excerpt: A single-use arbitrary string or number generated for verification purposes to prevent replaying past transactions.

o.title: Off-chain
o.excerpt: Transactions that occur off a given blockchain network, that may be later reported or batched together before submitted to the main chain.

o.title: Offshore account
o.excerpt: An account that is registered in a jurisdiction that is different to the jurisdiction of the holder's citizenship.

o.title: One Cancels the Other Order OCO
o.excerpt: A pair of orders that are created concurrently, but it is only possible for one of them to execute.

o.title: Open-Source Software OSS
o.excerpt: Software released under a license that gives anyone the ability and right to use, update, and distribute it freely.

o.title: Oracle
o.excerpt: A data source or feed from a third party used for determining outcomes for smart contracts

o.title: Order Book
o.excerpt: An electronic list of outstanding buy and sell orders for a specific asset on an exchange or marketplace.

o.title: Orphan Block
o.excerpt: A block whose parent block is unknown, formed in older versions of Bitcoin Core, where ancestry data wasn't required.

p.title: Paper Wallet
p.excerpt: A piece of paper on which a cryptocurrency address and its corresponding private key are physically printed out.

p.title: Passive Management
p.excerpt: An investing strategy that doesn’t rely on active market exposure but rather tracks an existing economic index.

p.title: Peer-to-Peer P2P
p.excerpt: When two or more computers are connected and share workload or resources without relying on a centralized server.

p.title: Pegged Currency
p.excerpt: A currency where the price is designed to remain the same as a designated asset. For example: 1 USDT is pegged to 1 USD. Also referred to as a stablecoin.

p.title: Phishing
p.excerpt: A malicious attack where a bad actor will attempt to obtain the credentials of a user in order to gain unauthorised access into their account.

p.title: Plasma
p.excerpt: An Ethereum off-chain scaling solution which may allow Etherum to greatly increase the transactions per second capablities.

p.title: Polkadot Crowdloan
p.excerpt: Polkadot Crowdloan refers to the process of staking Polkadot DOT tokens to support specific projects in the Polkadot Slot Auction. In return, participants can receive rewards from the projects.

p.title: Ponzi Scheme
p.excerpt: A scam in which new investors' funds are used to pay returns promised to previous investors. Do not invest in these.

p.title: Price Action
p.excerpt: The price movements of a financial asset over time. Plotted on a chart, it can be used by traders to identify trade setups.

p.title: Prisoner's Dilemma
p.excerpt: An example that shows why two individuals might not cooperate, even if it may appear to be in their best interest.

p.title: Private Key
p.excerpt: In cryptocurrency, a private key is a lengthy number that allows users to sign transactions and to generate receiving addresses.

p.title: Private Sale
p.excerpt: An early stage investment round for strategic investors with a considerable amount of investible funds.

p.title: Progressive Web application PWA
p.excerpt: An application that is created through the use of modern web technologies and follows basic web standards.

p.title: Proof of Attendance Protocol POAP
p.excerpt: A protocol that creates digital badges or collectibles to celebrate and record the attendance of an event.

p.title: Proof of Stake PoS
p.excerpt: A consensus mechanism that reward block validators according to the amount of coins they have at stake.

p.title: Pseudorandom
p.excerpt: The property of a definite function that can produce an outcome that passes statistical tests of randomness.

q.title: Quantum Computing
q.excerpt: Quantum computing works using particles that can be in superposition. These particles represent qubits instead of bits and can take the value of 1, 0 or both simultaneously.

r.title: Race attack
r.excerpt: When two transactions are created with the same funds at the same time, with the intention of spending those funds twice.

r.title: Ransomware
r.excerpt: A type of malware which takes over your computer and threatens to destroy or reveal files unless a ransom is paid.

r.title: Rekt
r.excerpt: A slang term used to define someone or something that has been destroyed or experienced catastrophic failure and a synonym for liquidated

r.title: Relative Strength Index RSI
r.excerpt: A technical indicator that measures market momentum & used to identify overbought and oversold conditions.

r.title: Resistance
r.excerpt: A term in Technical Analysis TA. When a price that is increasing finds resistance. Usually compared with previous highs.

r.title: Return on Investment ROI
r.excerpt: A measure used in order to assess the efficiency of an investment. The ratio between net profit and net cost.

r.title: Roadmap
r.excerpt: A business planning technique which lays out the short and long term goals of a company within a flexible estimated timeline.

r.title: Routing Attack
r.excerpt: An attack on the Internet Service Provider level to affect uptime or participation in a web-enabled system, such as a blockchain.

r.title: Rug pull
r.excerpt: A rug pull in the crypto industry is when a development team suddenly abandons a project and sells or removes all its liquidity.

s.title: Satoshi
s.excerpt: The smallest unit of a bitcoin, as defined by the Bitcoin protocol. It equals one-hundred-millionth of a bitcoin or 0.00000001 BTC.

s.title: Satoshi Nakamoto
s.excerpt: The pseudonym of the creator or creators of the bitcoin protocol and whitepaper.

s.title: Secure Asset Fund for Users SAFU
s.excerpt: Secure Asset Fund for Users is an emergency insurance fund created by Binance in 2018.

s.title: Securities and Exchange Commission SEC
s.excerpt: An independent governmental agency responsible for regulating securities markets.

s.title: Security Audit
s.excerpt: A systematic analysis to evaluate how safe a system, smart contract, or blockchain is agaisnt attacks or technical failures.

s.title: Seed Phrase
s.excerpt: A seed phrase or menmonic seed is a collection of words that can be used to access your cryptocurrency wallet.

s.title: Segregated Witness SegWit
s.excerpt: A process where the transaction signatures are separated from bitcoin transactions. Allowing more transactions to fit within one block.

s.title: Selfish Mining
s.excerpt: The strategic withholding and releasing of blocks by a miner in order to gain a competitive advantage over the network.

s.title: Sell Wall
s.excerpt: A very large limit sell order or a cumulation of sell orders at the same price level on an order book for an asset.

s.title: Server
s.excerpt: Server

s.title: Sentiment
s.excerpt: The overall attitude of a community in regards to a cryptocurrency or within investors towards a certain financial market.

s.title: Sharpe Ratio
s.excerpt: A ratio created in 1966 that investors and economists use to assess the potential return of investment ROI.

s.title: Smart Contract
s.excerpt: Automated contracts that trigger certain action when predetermined conditions are met. It works like 'If…then' conditions as for instance, it needs condition C met before money can be transferred from A to B.

s.title: Snapshot
s.excerpt: The ability to record the state of a blockchain ledger, storage device, or computer system at a specific point in time.

s.title: Source Code
s.excerpt: Computer code, which is responsible for defining how software will function based on a list of instructions and statements.

s.title: Stablecoin
s.excerpt: A type of cryptocurrency that is designed to maintain a stable value, rather than experiencing significant price changes.

s.title: Staking Pool
s.excerpt: A pool where stakeholders combine their staking power to increase their chance of successfully validating a new block.

s.title: State Channel
s.excerpt: A two-way communication channel between two users or nodes on a network, or between a user and a service.

s.title: Store of Value
s.excerpt: A commodity, asset or currency that can be saved, retrieved and exchanged at a future date, without suffering depreciation.

s.title: Supercomputer
s.excerpt: A computer or virtual machine that operates at the highest level of currently possible computing power.

s.title: Supply Chain
s.excerpt: A network of people and businesses involved in creating and distributing a particular product or serving a particular customer.

s.title: Support
s.excerpt: A term in Technical Analysis TA. When a price that is decreasing finds 'support'. Usually compared with lows.

t.title: Taker
t.excerpt: The 'taker' is someone who decides to place an order that is instantly matched with an existing order on the order book.

t.title: Tank
t.excerpt: A term adopted from the traditional financial markets and describes a strong negative financial performance of a particular asset

t.title: Ticker
t.excerpt: The trading 'symbol' or shortened name typically in capital letters that refer to a coin on a trading platform. For example: BNB

t.title: Token
t.excerpt: Tokens not to be confused with coins are digital units issued on a blockchain. They can hold value or be redeemed for assets.

t.title: Token Lockup
t.excerpt: Token lockup or vesting period refers to the time span in which tokens or coins are not allowed to be transferred or traded.

t.title: Token Sale
t.excerpt: The issuance of tokens in exchange for another cryptocurrency. Also referred to as an Initial Coin Offering.

t.title: Total Supply
t.excerpt: Refers to the number of coins or tokens that currently exists and are either in circulation or locked somehow.

t.title: Transaction ID TXID
t.excerpt: A transaction ID TXID is a unique string of characters that labels each transaction on the blockchain.

t.title: Transactions Per Second TPS
t.excerpt: The number of transactions that a blockchain network is capable of processing each second.

t.title: Trustless
t.excerpt: No single entity has authority over the system and consensus is achieved between participants who do not have to trust each other.

t.title: Turing Complete
t.excerpt: A machine that, given enough time and memory along with the necessary instructions, can solve any computational problem, no matter how complex.

u.title: Unit of Account
u.excerpt: One of the primary properties of money. Allowing measurement and comparison of the value of different things.

u.title: Unspent Transaction Output UTXO
u.excerpt: An output created in a transaction, which must be referenced in a future transaction to spend funds.

u.title: User Interface UI
u.excerpt: The interface where interactions between humans and machines occur. It establishes how a user can interact with a machine.

v.title: Verification Code
v.excerpt: Code sent to a second device to ensure the identity of someone logging in to an account. Used for Two-Factor Authentication

v.title: Virtual Machine
v.excerpt: An emulated computer system, or a distributed system that is designed to replicate the features of a computer's architecture.

v.title: Vladimir Club
v.excerpt: A term used to describe someone who has acquired 1% of 1% 0.01% of the maximum supply of a cryptocurrency.

v.title: Volatility
v.excerpt: How quickly and how much the price of an asset changes. Calculated in terms of standard deviations in the annual return of an asset over a set period of time.

v.title: Volume
v.excerpt: A measurement of the number of individual units of an asset that changed hands in a market during a given time.

w.title: Wallet
w.excerpt: Used to send and receive cryptocurrencies. Different types include software wallets, hardware wallets, and paper wallets.

w.title: Weak Hands
w.excerpt: A term referring to traders or investors who lack the confidence to hold their assets or to follow their trading plans.

w.title: Weak Subjectivity
w.excerpt: Relates to the need for certain nodes to rely on other nodes when determining the current state of a PoS blockchain.

w.title: Web 1.0
w.excerpt: The initial iteration of the web, when data was primarily read-only pages connected with hyperlinks. Also known as 'read-only' web.

w.title: Wei
w.excerpt: The smallest possible denomination of ether ETH, the currency used on the Ethereum network. Often used when referring to gas prices.

w.title: Whale
w.excerpt: An individual or organization that holds a large amount of Bitcoins or other cryptocurrency, allowing them to impact the markets.

w.title: Whiskers
w.excerpt: The lines extending from the colored bar in a candlestick chart that indicate the full low-high range of a trading pair within a certain time frame. Also referred to as wicks or shadows.

w.title: Whitelist
w.excerpt: A list of allowed or trusted individuals, computer programs, or cryptocurrency addresses in relation to a service or event.

w.title: Wick
w.excerpt: A line found on a candlestick chart which is used to indicate where the price of an asset is fluctuating in regards to its opening and closing prices.

w.title: Wrapped Ether WETH
w.excerpt: ERC-20 token representing Ether at a 1:1 ratio. It allows users to trade ETH to ERC-20 tokens on decentralized platforms.

z.title: Zero-Knowledge Proofs
z.excerpt: Proofs to verify that transactions are valid without revealing any information about these transactions, providing privacy to the transaction while maintaining its legitimacy.

z.title: Zk-Snarks
z.excerpt: “Zero-Knowledge Succinct Non-Interactive Argument of Knowledge” - an approach to zero knowledge proofs.
